steps.title: Identify the least common multiple for the fractions.
steps.content: Identify the least common multiple for the fractions. According to math tutor David Jia, the first thing you have to do is find a common denominator. [1] X Expert Source David Jia Academic Tutor Expert Interview. 23 February 2021. List out the multiples of each denominator in the problem until you find a number that all the fractions have in common. [2] X Research source Let’s say you’re comparing three fractions: 5 / 8 {\displaystyle 5/8} , 2 / 3 {\displaystyle 2/3} , and 3 / 4 {\displaystyle 3/4} . You’d list of several multiples of 8 (8, 16, 24), 3 (3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24), and 4 (4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24). In this example, 24 would be the least common denominator. Alternative: Multiply all the denominators together to get the LCM. For example, if you’re comparing 2 / 3 {\displaystyle 2/3} , 5 / 6 {\displaystyle 5/6} , and 1 / 3 {\displaystyle 1/3} , you’d multiply 6 and 3 to get 18 as the LCM (you’d only need to multiply by 3 once).

steps.title: Convert any mixed numbers to improper fractions.
steps.content: Convert any mixed numbers to improper fractions. Mixed numbers are a combination of whole numbers and fractions, like 32 / 3 {\displaystyle 32/3} . To order them properly with other fractions, you need to convert them to an improper fraction (a fraction with a higher numerator than denominator): Separate the whole number from the fraction. In our example, that would be 3 and 2/3. Multiply the whole number by the denominator of the fraction. In our example, you’d multiply 3 / 1 {\displaystyle 3/1} by 3 / 3 {\displaystyle 3/3} , giving you 9 / 3 {\displaystyle 9/3} . Add the numerators of the improper fraction and leftover fraction together. In our example, 9 / 3 + 2 / 3 {\displaystyle 9/3+2/3} would become 11 / 3 {\displaystyle 11/3} .

steps.title: Adjust the fractions so they all have the same denominator.
steps.content: Adjust the fractions so they all have the same denominator. Now that you know the LCM, multiply the numerator and denominator by the same number—whichever number turns the denominator into the LCM. In our example, for instance, 5 / 8 {\displaystyle 5/8} would be multiplied by 3 / 3 {\displaystyle 3/3} to make 15 / 24 {\displaystyle 15/24} , with 24 being the LCM. [3] X Research source To continue with the previous example, we’d multiply 2 / 3 {\displaystyle 2/3} by 8 / 8 {\displaystyle 8/8} to get 16 / 24 {\displaystyle 16/24} and 3 / 4 {\displaystyle 3/4} by 6 / 6 {\displaystyle 6/6} to get 18 / 24 {\displaystyle 18/24} .

steps.title: Use the numerators to order the fractions from least to greatest.
steps.content: Use the numerators to order the fractions from least to greatest. Now that the denominators are the same, list the fractions from the smallest numerator to the largest numerator. You’ve now successfully ordered fractions! The correct order of fractions from our previous example would be: 5 / 8 ( 15 / 24 ) , 2 / 3 ( 16 / 24 ) , 3 / 4 ( 18 / 24 ) {\displaystyle 5/8(15/24),2/3(16/24),3/4(18/24)} .

steps.title: Divide by the original number to convert the fractions to their original numbers.
steps.content: Divide by the original number to convert the fractions to their original numbers. According to Jia, you can “simplify by dividing the top and bottom by whatever their common factors are.” [4] X Expert Source David Jia Academic Tutor Expert Interview. 23 February 2021. Let’s go back to the example of 5 / 8 {\displaystyle 5/8} , which we converted to 15 / 24 {\displaystyle 15/24} by multiplying the original fraction by 3 / 3 {\displaystyle 3/3} . Now that we’ve successfully ordered the fractions, we can convert 15 / 24 {\displaystyle 15/24} by dividing both the numerator and denominator by 3, which gives us 5 / 8 {\displaystyle 5/8} again.

steps.title: Order the fractions from the largest denominator to the smallest denominator.
steps.content: Order the fractions from the largest denominator to the smallest denominator. The denominator (bottom number) describes how many pieces a whole is broken into. The larger the number, the more pieces there are—and, more importantly, the smaller those pieces are. To order fractions with identical numerators (top numbers) but different denominators from least to greatest, work your way from the fractions with the largest denominators to the fractions with the smallest denominators. [5] X Research source Picture two circles, with one divided into 10 pieces and the other divided into 5 pieces. A 1 / 10 {\displaystyle 1/10} slice would be smaller than a 1 / 5 {\displaystyle 1/5} slice.

steps.title: Order the fractions from the smallest numerator to the largest numerator.
steps.content: Order the fractions from the smallest numerator to the largest numerator. When the denominators (bottom numbers) are identical, all you have to do is organize the numerators (top numbers) in numerical order. So, the fraction with the smallest numerator would go on one end, while the fraction with the largest numerator would go on the opposite side. [6] X Research source Imagine you have two fractions: 2 / 8 {\displaystyle 2/8} and 5 / 8 {\displaystyle 5/8} . The 2 / 8 {\displaystyle 2/8} fraction would be considered smaller, since it incorporates fewer total pieces of the pie.

steps.title: Write the two fractions next to each other.
steps.content: Write the two fractions next to each other. For example, let’s compare the fraction 3 / 5 {\displaystyle 3/5} and the fraction 2 / 3 {\displaystyle 2/3} . Write these next to each other on the page: 3 / 5 {\displaystyle 3/5} on the left, and 2 / 3 {\displaystyle 2/3} on the right.

steps.title: Multiply the top of the first fraction with the bottom of the second fraction.
steps.content: Multiply the top of the first fraction with the bottom of the second fraction. In our example, the top number, or numerator , of the first fraction ( 3 / 5 {\displaystyle 3/5} ) is 3 . The bottom number, or denominator , of the second fraction ( 2 / 3 {\displaystyle 2/3} ) is also 3 . Multiply these together: 3 x 3 = ? {\displaystyle 3x3=?} [7] X Research source This method is called cross-multiplication because you multiply numbers in a diagonal line across from each other.

steps.title: Write your answer next to the first fraction.
steps.content: Write your answer next to the first fraction. Write the product, or answer to your multiplication problem, next to the first fraction on the page. In our example, 3 x 3 = 9 {\displaystyle 3x3=9} , so you would write 9 next to the first fraction, on the left side of the page.

steps.title: Multiply the top of the second fraction with the bottom of the first.
steps.content: Multiply the top of the second fraction with the bottom of the first . To find out which fraction is larger, we'll need to compare our answer above with the answer to another multiplication problem. Multiply these two numbers together. For our example (comparing 3/5 and 2/3), multiply 2 x 5 {\displaystyle 2x5} together. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Write this answer next to the second fraction.
steps.content: Write this answer next to the second fraction. In this example, the answer is 10.

steps.title: Compare the values of the two cross-products.
steps.content: Compare the values of the two cross-products. The answers to the multiplication problems in this method are called cross-products . If one cross-product is larger than the other, then the fraction next to that cross-product is also larger than the other fraction. In our example, because 9 is less than 10, this means 3 / 5 {\displaystyle 3/5} must be less than 2 / 3 {\displaystyle 2/3} . [9] X Research source Remember, always write the cross-product next to the fraction whose top number you used.

steps.title: Order the fractions based on your results.
steps.content: Order the fractions based on your results. Cross-multiply fractions all the fractions within the series to figure out which ones are the biggest and smallest. Place the fractions in correct order to finish the puzzle.

9/10, 2/5, 1/2, 4/5 The LCM for this problem is 10, which would be your target denominator for all the fractions in this puzzle. Upon conversion, the fractions would read as: 9/10, 2/5, 1/2, 8/10. From there, it’s a simple matter of reordering the fractions using the numerators as a reference. Answer: 2/5, 1/2, 4/5, 9/10

2/5, 1/3, 2/4, 3/5 The LCM of these fractions is 60 , so your first step is converting all the fractions so they have 60 as a denominator. From there, order the numerators from least to greatest, which gives you 1/3 (20/60), 2/5 (24/60), 2/4 (30/60), 3/5 (36/60) Answer: 1/3, 2/5, 2/4, 3/5

3/4, 7/8, 3/16 Start by calculating the LCM, which is 16 . Adjust 3/4 and 7/8 so they share this denominator, transforming these fractions into 12/16 and 14/16. From there, order the numbers from least to greatest using the numerators, and then convert them back to their original form. Answer: 3/16, 3/4, 7/8
